([[WP:TW|TW]]) wikitext text/x-wiki {{redirect|Lauper|the curler|Erwin Lauper}} {{Use mdy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox person |name = Cyndi Lauper |image = Cyndi australia 2011 2.png |caption = Cyndi Lauper performing in Australia, 2011, during the Memphis Blues Tour |birth_name = Cynthia Ann Stephanie Lauper |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1953|6|22}} |birth_place = [[Astoria, Queens|Astoria]], [[Queens]], [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] |spouse = {{marriage|[[David Thornton (actor)|David Thornton]]|1991}} |children = 1 |occupation = Singer, songwriter, actress, activist |years_active = 1977–present |module = {{Infobox musical artist|embed=yes |background = solo_singer |instrument = Vocals |genre = [[Pop music|Pop]], [[Rock music|rock]], [[New wave music|new wave]], [[synthpop]], [[Blues music|blues]], [[Soul music|soul]] |label = [[Portrait Records|Portrait]], [[Epic Records|Epic]], [[Daylight Records|Daylight]], [[Downtown Records|Downtown]], [[Sire Records|Sire]] |associated_acts = [[Blue Angel (band)|Blue Angel]], [[The Hooters]] }} |website = {{URL|cyndilauper.com}} |signature = Cyndi's signature.png }} '''Cynthia Ann Stephanie "Cyndi" Lauper''' (born June 22, 1953){{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/44/Cyndi-Lauper.html |title=Cyndi Lauper Biography (1953–) |publisher=Filmreference.com |date= |accessdate=April 19, 2014}} is an American singer, songwriter, actress and [[LGBT]] activist.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/cyndi-lauper/give-a-damn_b_1000046.html|title=Give a Damn|work=[[The Huffington Post]]}} Her career has spanned over 30 years. Her debut solo album ''[[She's So Unusual]]'' (1983) was the first debut female album to chart four top-five hits on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]]—"[[Girls Just Want to Have Fun]]", "[[Time After Time (Cyndi Lauper song)|Time After Time]]", "[[She Bop]]", and "[[All Through the Night (Cyndi Lauper song)|All Through the Night]]"—and earned Lauper the [[Grammy Award for Best New Artist|Best New Artist]] award at the [[27th Grammy Awards]] in 1985. Her success continued with the soundtrack for the motion picture ''[[The Goonies]]'' and her second record ''[[True Colors (Cyndi Lauper album)|True Colors]]'' (1986). This album included the number one [[True Colors (Cyndi Lauper song)|hit of the same name]] and "[[Change of Heart (Cyndi Lauper song)|Change of Heart]]", which peaked at number 3. Since 1989, Lauper has released nine studio albums and participated in many other projects. In 2010, ''[[Memphis Blues (album)|Memphis Blues]]'', became ''Billboard's'' most successful blues album of the year, remaining at #1 on the ''Billboard'' Blues Albums chart for 13 consecutive weeks. In 2013, Lauper won the Tony Award for Best Original Score for composing the Broadway musical ''[[Kinky Boots (musical)|Kinky Boots]]'', making her the first woman to win the category by herself.{{cite web|title=The Tony Award Nominees |url= http://www.tonyawards.com/en_US/nominees/index.html |accessdate=June 9, 2013}} The musical was awarded five other Tonys including Tony Award for Best New Musical. In 2014, Lauper was awarded the [[Grammy Award for Best Musical Theater Album]] for [[Kinky Boots (Broadway cast album)|the cast recording]]. In 2016 the West End production won Best New Musical at the Olivier Awards {{cite web |url= http://deadline.com/2016/04/kinky-boots-in-the-heights-judi-dench-olivier-awards-1201731314/ |title=London Loves Lin-Manuel Miranda Too (And ‘Kinky Boots’ & Judi Dench) – Olivier Awards |first=Jeremy |last=Gerard |date=April 4, 2016 |work=deadline.com |accessdate=July 27, 2016}} Lauper has established herself as a [[pop culture]] icon{{cite web |url= http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/reliable-source/wp/2014/10/22/cause-celeb-cyndi-lauper-advocates-for-homeless-youth/| first= Emily |last= Heil|title=Cause Celeb: Cyndi Lauper advocates for homeless youth |work=Washington Post |date=October 22, 2014}} selling over 50 million albums and 20 million singles.{{cite web |url= http://www.ticketwarehouse.com/concert-tickets/pop/cyndi-lauper.php |title=Cyndi Lauper Tickets – Buy Online |publisher=Ticketwarehouse.com |date= |accessdate=October 15, 2011}}{{cite web |url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/music/showcase/clips/p00mgyhj |title=BBC Music Showcase |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=February 12, 2012}} She has won awards at the [[Grammy Award|Grammys]], [[Emmy Award|Emmys]], [[Tony Award|Tonys]], the New York's Outer Critics Circle, [[MTV Video Music Award]]s (VMAs), [[Billboard Awards]], and [[American Music Awards]] (AMAs).{{cite web |url= http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/cyndi-lauper-wild-80s-girl-power-icon-parenting/story?id=18192583 |title=Cyndi Lauper, Wild '80s Girl Power Icon, on Parenting, Marriage |work=ABC News |accessdate=September 19, 2014}} An inductee into both the [[Songwriters Hall of Fame]] and the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]], Lauper is one of the few singers to win three of the four major American entertainment awards ([[EGOT]]).{{cite news |url= http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/02/18/songwriters-hall-of-fame-to-honor-toby-keith-cyndi-lauper-robert-hunter-and-jerry-garcia/?_r=0 |title=Songwriters Hall of Fame to Honor Toby Keith, Cyndi Lauper, Robert Hunter and Jerry Garcia |publisher=ArtsBeat |work=The New York Times| first= Joe| last= Coscarelli| date= February 18, 2015| access-date= July 29, 2016}} Lauper won the inaugural Best Female Video prize at the 1984 VMAs for ''[[Girls Just Wanna Have Fun]]''. This [[music video]] is recognized by [[MTV]], [[VH1]] and ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' as one of the greatest ever music videos of the era.{{cite web |url=http://www.rockonthenet.com/archive/1993/rsvideo.htm |title=Rolling Stone: "The 100 Top Music Videos" |publisher=Rockonthenet.com |accessdate=September 19, 2014}}{{cite web |first= Heather |last= Wood Rudolph |deadurl= yes| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20130518000747/http://sexyfeminist.com/2013/01/29/feminist-history-in-song-cyndi-laupers-girls-just-want-to-have-fun/| archivedate= May 18, 2013 |url=http://sexyfeminist.com/2013/01/29/feminist-history-in-song-cyndi-laupers-girls-just-want-to-have-fun/ |title=Feminist History In Song: Cyndi Lauper's 'Girls Just Want to Have Fun' |work=The Sexy Feminist ''blog'' |date=January 29, 2013 |accessdate=April 19, 2014}}{{cite web |url= http://www.rockonthenet.com/archive/1999/mtv100.htm |title=MTV: '100 Greatest Music Videos Ever Made'| website=Rockonthenet.com |accessdate=September 19, 2014}}{{cite web |url= http://www.rockonthenet.com/archive/2001/vh1videos.htm |title=VH1: 100 Greatest Videos |publisher=Rockonthenet.com |accessdate=September 19, 2014}} She is featured in the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Museum]]'s ''Women Who Rock'' exhibit.{{cite web|last=Morrison |first=Shelby |url= http://www.rockhall.com/blog/post/10267_30-year-anniversary--cyndi-lauper-shes-so-unusual/ |title=30 Years Later: Cyndi Lauper's "She's So Unusual" | The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum |publisher=Rockhall.com |date=April 15, 2013 |accessdate=April 19, 2014}} Her debut album is included in ''[[Rolling Stone]]'''s list of the [[500 Greatest Albums of All Time]],{{cite web |url= http://www.rockonthenet.com/archive/2003/rs500albums1.htm |title=Rolling Stone's 500 Greatest Albums| website= Rockonthenet.com| accessdate=September 19, 2014}} while ''[[Time After Time (Cyndi Lauper song)|Time After Time]]'' is included in [[Vh1]]'s list of the 100 Best Songs of the Past 25 years.{{cite web |url= http://www.rockonthenet.com/archive/2003/vh125songs.htm |title=VH1's Best Songs of the Past 25 years |publisher=Rockonthenet.com |accessdate=September 19, 2014}} [[VH1]] has ranked Lauper No. 58 of the ''100 Greatest Women of Rock & Roll''.{{cite web| url= http://www.rockonthenet.com/archive/1999/vh1women.htm |title=VH1: 100 Greatest Women of Rock & Roll |website= Rockonthenet.com|date= |accessdate=October 15, 2011}} Lauper has been celebrated for her humanitarian work, particularly as an advocate for gay and transgender rights in the United States. Her charitable efforts were acknowledged in 2013 when the singer was invited as a special guest to attend US President [[Barack Obama]]'s second-term inaugural.{{cite news| url= http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/obamas-inauguration-adds-cyndi-lauper-412658/ | work=The Hollywood Reporter | first=Tina | last=Daunt | title=Cyndi Lauper, Ben Folds, Others Join Lineup for Obama's Inaugural |date= January 15, 2013| access-date= July 29, 2016}} ==Life and career== ===1953–1979: Early life=== Lauper was born at Boulevard Hospital in [[Astoria, Queens]], [[New York City]],{{cite news|author=Hoffman, Jan| url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E06E2D7113EF932A05751C1A9659C8B63 |title=PUBLIC LIVES; She Just Wanted to Have Fun. And She's Having It|work=[[The New York Times]]|date= December 31, 2003|accessdate=October 10, 2007}} to a Catholic family. Her father, Fred, was of German and Swiss descent. Her mother, Catrine (née Gallo), is Italian American (from [[Sicily]]). Lauper's siblings are younger brother Fred (nicknamed Butch), and older sister, Ellen.{{cite news|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1285/is_8_31/ai_77336634|title=Cyndi Lauper – and Lou Reed.}}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Lauper's parents divorced when she was five.{{cite web|url=http://www.biography.com/people/cyndi-lauper-17169536 |title=Cyndi Lauper Biography |publisher=Biography.com |accessdate=April 19, 2014}} Her mother remarried and divorced again.Cyndi Lauper Bio, http://www.cyndilaupersite.com Lauper grew up in the [[Ozone Park, Queens|Ozone Park]]{{cite news| work=WETV| date=November 19, 2012| title=10 Things You Didn't Know About Cyndi Lauper| url=http://www.wetv.com/cyndi/articles/10-things-you-didn%E2%80%99t-know-about-cyndi-lauper}} neighborhood of Queens and, as a child, listened to such artists as [[The Beatles]], [[Ella Fitzgerald]], [[Judy Garland]] and [[Billie Holiday]]. At age 12, she began writing songs and playing an [[acoustic guitar]] given to her by her sister.{{cite news|title=Cyndi Lauper: two decades after blazing the way for a generation of female pop singers, the original day-glo diva is reigniting her career with a collection of songs as colorful as she is.(Interview)|author=McDonnell, Evelyn|date=December 1, 2003|publisher=Brant Publications, Inc.}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.boomsbeat.com/articles/21911/20150804/50-interesting-things-singer-cyndi-lauper.htm|title=50 interesting facts about singer Cyndi Lauper|date=2015-08-04|website=BOOMSbeat|access-date=2016-02-28}} Lauper expressed herself with a variety of hair colors, eccentric clothing{{cite news| work=On the Media| first=Brooke| last=Gladstone |title=Interview With Cyndi Lauper}} and even took a friend's advice to spell her name as "Cyndi" rather than "Cindy". Lauper went to [[Richmond Hill High School (Queens)|Richmond Hill High School]], but was expelled,{{cite news| work=The New York Times | date=November 30, 2012| title=Sunday Book Review – Cyndi Lauper: A Memoir| url=http://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/02/books/review/cyndi-lauper-a-memoir.html}} although she later earned her [[General Educational Development|GED]].{{Cite web | url = http://adulted.about.com/od/gettingyourged/tp/25-More-Celebrity-Dropouts-Who-Earned-A-Ged-List-No-2.htm | title = Celebrity Dropouts Who Earned a GED, List No. 2 | website = About.com Education | access-date = 2016-02-28 }}{{Cite web | url = http://lyrics.songonlyrics.net/cyndi-lauper-biography | title = Cyndi Lauper Biography | website = Song Lyrics – Music Lyrics – Newest Lyrics With Video | access-date = 2016-02-28 }} She left home at 17, to escape her abusive [[stepfather]], intending to study art. Her journey took her to Canada, where she spent two weeks in the woods with her dog Sparkle, trying to find herself. She eventually traveled to [[Vermont]], where she took art classes at [[Johnson State College]] and supported herself working odd jobs.{{Cite web | url = http://www.rollingstone.com/music/features/dream-girl-19840524?page=3 | title = Cyndi Lauper: Dream Girl | website = Rolling Stone | access-date = 2016-02-28 }}{{Cite web | url = http://www.bornrich.com/cyndi-lauper.html | title = Cyndi Lauper – Bornrich | website = Bornrich | language = en-US | access-date = 2016-02-28 }} In the early 1970s, Lauper performed as a vocalist with various [[cover band]]s. One, called Flyer, was active in the New York metropolitan area, singing hits by bands including [[Bad Company]], [[Jefferson Airplane]] and [[Led Zeppelin]]. Although Lauper was performing on stage, she was not happy singing [[cover version|cover]]s.{{Cite web | url = http://www.boomsbeat.com/articles/21911/20150804/50-interesting-things-singer-cyndi-lauper.htm | title = 50 interesting facts about singer Cyndi Lauper | date = 2015-08-04 | website = BOOMSbeat | access-date = 2016-02-28 }} In 1977, Lauper damaged her vocal cords and took a year off from singing. She was told by doctors that she would never sing again, but regained her voice with the help of vocal coach Katie Agresta.{{cite web|url=http://www.cyndilaupersite.com/biography/ |title=Biography | Cyndi Lauper – Photos, Videos, Music, Biography |publisher=Cyndilaupersite.com |date= |accessdate=April 19, 2014}} ===1980–1982: ''Blue Angel''=== {{Main article|Blue Angel (band)|l1=Blue Angel}} In 1978, Lauper met saxophone player [[John Turi]] through her manager Ted Rosenblatt. Turi and Lauper formed a band named ''Blue Angel'' and recorded a demo tape of original music. [[Steven Massarsky|Steve Massarsky]], manager of [[The Allman Brothers Band]],{{cite web|last1=Anderson|first1=Porter|title=Steve Massarsky: Starting small with BIG|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2000/CAREER/jobenvy/09/29/steve.massarsky/|website=cnn.com|publisher=Cable News Network|accessdate=September 24, 2014}} heard the tape and liked Lauper's voice. He bought Blue Angel's contract for $5,000 and became their manager.{{Cite web | url = http://www.rollingstone.com/music/features/dream-girl-19840524?page=4 | title = Cyndi Lauper: Dream Girl | website = Rolling Stone | access-date = 2016-02-28 }} Lauper received recording offers as a solo artist, but held out, wanting the band to be included in any deal she made. Blue Angel was eventually signed by [[Polydor Records]] and released a self-titled album on the label in 1980. Lauper hated the album cover, saying that it made her look like [[Big Bird]], but ''Rolling Stone'' magazine later included it as one of the 100 best [[New wave music|new wave]] album covers (2003). Despite critical acclaim, the album sold poorly (or "It went lead", as Lauper later joked.) and the band broke up. The members of Blue Angel had a falling-out with Massarsky and fired him as their manager. He later filed an $80,000 suit against them, which forced Lauper into bankruptcy.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/music/artist/lauper_cyndi/artist.jhtml|title=Cyndi Lauper|publisher=MTV|accessdate=March 1, 2010}} After this Lauper temporarily lost her voice due to an inverted cyst in her vocal cord.{{cite news|first=David|last=Chiu |url=http://time.com/65952/cyndi-lauper-shes-so-unusual/ |title=Cyndi Lauper's She's So Unusual Is 30: New Tour With Cher, Kinky Boots |work=TIME |date= |accessdate=April 19, 2014}} After Blue Angel broke up and, due to her financial problems, Lauper spent time working in retail stores, waitressing at [[IHOP]] (which she quit after being demoted to hostess when the manager made a pass at her), and singing in local clubs. Her most frequent gigs were at El Sombrero. Music critics who saw Lauper perform with Blue Angel believed she had star potential due to her four-octave singing range,Jerome, Jim. [http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20088685,00.html "She Wants to Have Fun"], ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'', September 17, 1984. Retrieved September 30, 2008. In 1981, while singing in a local New York bar, Lauper met David Wolff, who took over as her manager and had her sign a recording contract with [[Portrait Records]], a subsidiary of [[Epic Records]].{{cite web |title=Cyndi Lauper |url= http://www.lifetimetv.co.uk/biography/biography-cyndi-lauper |website=Lifetime.co.uk/ |publisher=AETN UK |accessdate=September 24, 2014}} ===1983–1985: ''She's So Unusual''=== {{Main article|She's So Unusual}} On October 14, 1983, Lauper released her first solo album, ''[[She's So Unusual]]''. The album peaked at No. 4 in the US, and became a worldwide hit. The primary studio musicians were [[Eric Bazilian]] and [[Rob Hyman]] (of [[The Hooters]]), [[Rick Chertoff]], [[Richard Termini]] and Peter Wood. Lauper became popular with teenagers and critics, in part due to her hybrid punk image, which was crafted by stylist Patrick Lucas.{{cite news |url= http://articles.latimes.com/1985-02-08/news/vw-4846_1_freckles-show |title=Capturing Head-to-Toe Look of the '80s |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |date=February 8, 1985 |accessdate=October 15, 2011 |first=Mary |last=Rourke}} {{listen |pos=left|filename=Cyndi Lauper - Girls Just Want To Have Fun.ogg|title="Girls Just Want To Have Fun".|Type=single}} Lauper was interested in writing her own songs, but the record company provided her with songs to record that were written by other writers. Lauper sometimes changed the lyrics in the material she was given by the record company; such is the case with "[[Girls Just Want to Have Fun]]". Lauper found the original lyrics to be misogynistic, so she rewrote the song as an anthem for young women.{{cite news |first=Priya |last=Elan |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/sep/27/popandrock |title=Music: Priya Elan pays tribute to the man who wrote Girls Just Want To Have Fun |newspaper=The Guardian |date=September 27, 2008 |accessdate=October 15, 2011 |location=London}} The album's second single "[[Time After Time (Cyndi Lauper song)|Time After Time]]" was co-written by Lauper and Rob Hyman. "Time After Time" hit No. 1 on both the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] and Adult Contemporary charts. The song would earn Lauper an [[Gold record|RIAA Gold certification]] for record sales that reached 500,000 copies. The other [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] singles on ''She's So Unusual'' were "[[She Bop]]" (No. 3), "[[All Through the Night (Cyndi Lauper song)|All Through the Night]]" (No. 5), written by [[Jules Shear]], and "[[Money Changes Everything]]" (No.27).http://www.billboard.com, chart history, September 8, 1984, December 8, 1984, February 9, 1985 The album includes two cover songs, [[The Brains]]' new wave track "[[Money Changes Everything]]" (No. 27 on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100) and [[Prince (musician)|Prince]]'s "[[When You Were Mine (Prince song)|When You Were Mine]]". The album made Lauper the first female to have four consecutive ''Billboard'' Hot 100 top five hits from one album. The LP stayed in the Top 200 charts for more than 65 weeks, and since has sold 22 million copies worldwide.{{cite web|first=Nick|last=Duerden |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/cyndi-lauper-interview-shes-still-having-fun-9235643.html |title=Cyndi Lauper interview: She's still having fun – Features – Music |newspaper=The Independent |date=April 4, 2014 |accessdate=April 19, 2014}} Lauper won [[Grammy Award for Best New Artist|Best New Artist]] at the [[1985 Grammy Awards]]. "She's So Unusual" also received nominations for [[Grammy Award for Album of the Year|Album of the Year]], [[Grammy Award for Record of the Year|Record of the Year]], [[Grammy Award for Best Female Pop Vocal Performance|Best Female Pop Vocal Performance]] (for "Girls Just Want to Have Fun"), and [[Grammy Award for Song of the Year|Song of the Year]] (for "Time After Time"). It also won the Grammy for [[Grammy Award for Best Recording Package|Best Album Package]], which went to the art director, [[Janet Perr]].{{Cite web |title = The GRAMMYs' Trailblazing Women, Part One|url = http://www.grammy.com/blogs/the-grammys-trailblazing-women-part-one |website = The GRAMMYs |access-date =February 20, 2016}}{{Cite web|title = Classic Album covers : She’s So Unusual – Cyndi Lauper|url = http://www.nevermindthebuspass.com/happiness-archive/classic-album-covers/classic-album-covers-shes-so-unusual-cyndi-lauper/ |website = Never Mind the Bus Pass |access-date = February 20, 2016|language = en-us}} The video for "Girls Just Want to Have Fun" won the inaugural award for Best Female Video at the 1984 MTV Video Music Awards, and made Lauper an MTV staple. The video featured professional wrestling [[Manager (professional wrestling)|manager]] "Captain" [[Lou Albano]] as Lauper's father, and her real-life mother, Catrine, as her mother,[https://celebrity.yahoo.com Cyndi Lauper Bio] and also featured her attorney, her manager, her brother Butch, and her dog Sparkle.{{Cite web |title = Julio Licinio's Blog: Discovery to change your life: "Girls just want to have fun" |url = http://juliolicinio.blogspot.ca/2013/09/girls-just-want-to-have-fun.html#!/2013/09/girls-just-want-to-have-fun.html |website = juliolicinio.blogspot.ca |access-date = 2016-02-21}} In 1984–85, Lauper appeared on the covers of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine, ''Time'', and ''Newsweek''. She appeared twice on the cover of ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'', and was named a ''[[Ms. (magazine)|Ms.]]'' magazine Woman of the Year in 1985.{{cite news | last = Paglia | first = Camille | title = Madonna – Finally, a Real Feminist | publisher = The New York Times | date = December 14, 1990 | url = http://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/14/opinion/madonna-finally-a-real-feminist.html | accessdate = May 4, 2013}} In 1985, Lauper participated in [[USA for Africa]]'s famine-relief fund-raising single "[[We Are the World]]", which sold more than 20 million copies since then.Matera, Joe. "'We are the World': 25 Years Later." ''Goldmine.''(February 12, 2010): pg. 28–31. Lauper appeared with [[professional wrestler]] [[Hulk Hogan]], who played her "bodyguard"{{Cite web |title = Cyndi Lauper Wrestler Biography |url = http://icelebritieshub.tumblr.com/post/100309042741/cyndi-lauper-wrestler-biography |website = icelebritieshub.tumblr.com |access-date = 2016-02-21}}{{Cite web|title = Cyndi Lauper – Online World of Wrestling|url = http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/bios/c/cyndi-lauper/ |website = www.onlineworldofwrestling.com |access-date = 2016-02-21}} and would also later make many appearances as herself in a number of the [[World Wrestling Entertainment|World Wrestling Federation]]'s "[[Rock 'n' Wrestling Connection]]" events, and played [[Wendi Richter]]'s manager in [[WrestleMania I|the inaugural WrestleMania event]].{{cite book |last=Ellison |first=Lillian |title=The Fabulous Moolah: First Goddess of the Squared Circle |year=2003 |isbn=978-0-06-001258-8 |publisher=ReaganBooks |page=170}} Dave Wolff, Lauper's boyfriend and manager at the time, was a wrestling fan as a boy, and engineered the rock and wrestling connection.{{Cite web | url = http://www.australiansportsentertainment.com/lauper.html | title = Cindi Lauper interview Rock N Roll Wrestling Cooldudesandhotbabes.com | website = www.australiansportsentertainment.com | access-date = February 28, 2016 }} In 1985, Lauper released the single "[[The Goonies 'R' Good Enough]]", from the soundtrack to the movie ''[[The Goonies]]'', and an accompanying video which featured several wrestling stars. The song reached number 10 on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 chart.{{Cite web | url = http://www.billboard.com/artist/299876/cyndi-lauper/chart | title = Cyndi Lauper – Chart history {{!}} Billboard | website = www.billboard.com | access-date =February 28, 2016 }} ===1986–1988: ''True Colors'' and ''Vibes''=== Lauper received two nominations at the [[28th Grammy Awards|1986 Grammy Awards]]: [[Grammy Award for Best Female Rock Vocal Performance|Best Female Rock Vocal Performance]] for "What a Thrill" and [[Grammy Award for Best Long Form Music Video|Best Long Form Music Video]] for ''Cyndi: Live in Paris''.[http://www.awardsandshows.com, Grammy Awards 1986]{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Awards & Shows. Lauper released her second album, ''[[True Colors (Cyndi Lauper album)|True Colors]]'', on September 15, 1986. It reached No. 4 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] and sold 2 million copies in the US. She increased her involvement in production and songwriting on her second album, co-writing most of the songs with [[Essra Mohawk]], [[John Turi]], [[Billy Steinberg]], and [[Tom Kelly (musician)|Tom Kelly]]. Guests included Angela Clemons-Patrick, [[Nile Rodgers]], [[Aimee Mann]], [[Billy Joel]], [[Adrian Belew]], [[The Bangles]], Ellie Greenwich and [[Rick Derringer]].{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} ''True Colors'' was not as commercially successful as ''She's So Unusual'', but it did contain three high-charting singles, including the title track, "[[True Colors (Cyndi Lauper song)|True Colors]]", which became Lauper's second song to hit No. 1 on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100; "[[Change of Heart (Cyndi Lauper song)|Change of Heart]]" (No. 3); and a cover of [[Marvin Gaye]]'s "[[What's Going On (song)|What's Going On]]" (No. 12). A fourth single from the album, "[[Boy Blue (Cyndi Lauper song)|Boy Blue]]", did not reach the top-40. She donated the proceeds of that song to [[AIDS]] research. The song "True Colors" (written by Steinberg and Kelly) was licensed to [[Kodak]] for use in its commercials.{{Cite web|title = True Colors by Cyndi Lauper Songfacts|url = http://www.songfacts.com/detail.php?id=3101 |website = www.songfacts.com |access-date = 2016-02-21}} In 1986, Lauper appeared on the [[Billy Joel]] album ''[[The Bridge (Billy Joel album)|The Bridge]]'', with a song called "Code of Silence". She is credited as having written the lyrics with Joel and she sings a duet with him. In the same year, Lauper also sang the [[theme song]] for the series ''[[Pee-wee's Playhouse]]'', credited as "Ellen Shaw". In 1987, David Wolff produced a concert film for Lauper called ''Cyndi: Live in Paris''. The concert was broadcast on [[HBO]].{{Cite web |url= http://bastetglasba.blogspot.ca/2010/06/blue-angelcyndi-lauper.html |title=Bastet Glasba: Blue Angel/Cyndi Lauper |website=bastetglasba.blogspot.ca |access-date=2016-02-28}} Lauper made her film debut in August 1988 in the quirky comedy ''[[Vibes (film)|Vibes]]'', alongside [[Jeff Goldblum]], [[Peter Falk]], and [[Julian Sands]]. Lauper played a psychic in search of a city of gold in South America. [[Ron Howard]] produced the film, with David Wolff as associate producer. To prepare for the role, Lauper took a few classes in [[finger wave|finger waving]] and hair setting at the Robert Fiance School of Beauty in New York, and studied with a few Manhattan psychics. The film flopped and was poorly received by critics.{{Cite web |url= http://www.filmbug.com/db/1180 |title=Cyndi Lauper – Filmbug |website=www.filmbug.com |access-date=2016-02-28}}{{Cite web |url= http://lyrics.songonlyrics.net/cyndi-lauper-biography |title=Cyndi Lauper Biography |website=Song Lyrics – Music Lyrics – Newest Lyrics With Video |access-date=2016-02-28}} Lauper contributed a track called "[[Hole in My Heart (All the Way to China)]]" for the ''Vibes'' soundtrack, but the song was not included. A music video was released, a high energy, comic action/adventure romp through a Chinese laundry. The song reached No. 54 on the US charts, but fared better in Australia, reaching No. 8. "Hole in My Heart (All the Way to China)" became the opening song on her 2008 Australian tour.{{Citation needed|date=December 2009}} ===1989–1992: ''A Night to Remember'' and marriage=== ''[[A Night to Remember (Cyndi Lauper album)|A Night to Remember]]'' – Lauper's third album – was released in the spring of 1989. The album had only one hit, the No. 6 single "[[I Drove All Night (Cyndi Lauper song)|I Drove All Night]]". Lauper received a Grammy nomination for Best Female Rock Vocal Performance at the [[1990 Grammy Awards]] for "I Drove All Night", but overall album sales for ''A Night to Remember'' were down. The music video for the album's song "My First Night Without You" was one of the first to be closed-captioned for the hearing impaired.{{cite web |url= http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1989-08-10/features/8902250169_1_captioning-videos-closed-captioned-deaf-community |title=Videos Closed-captioned – Sun Sentinel |publisher=Articles.sun-sentinel.com |date=August 10, 1989 |accessdate=April 19, 2014}} On July 21, 1990, Lauper joined [[Roger Waters]] and other artists performing "[[Another Brick in the Wall, Part II]]" as part of the concert [[The Wall – Live in Berlin|''The Wall'' in Berlin]]. As part of the concert, Lauper also performed "[[The Tide Is Turning]]" with Waters, [[Joni Mitchell]], [[Bryan Adams]], [[Paul Carrack]] and [[Van Morrison]]. Three hundred thousand people attended the concert and over five million people worldwide watched on live television.{{citation needed |date=September 2014}} Because of a friendship with [[Yoko Ono]], Lauper took part in the May 1990 [[John Lennon]] tribute concert in Liverpool, performing the Beatles song "Hey Bulldog" and the John Lennon song "Working Class Hero".{{cite web |author= |url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/liverpool/content/articles/2005/12/06/lennon_anniversary_feature.shtml |title=Liverpool – Beatles – Lennon remembered |publisher=BBC |date=May 20, 2008 |accessdate=April 19, 2014}} She also took part in Ono and Lennon's son [[Sean Lennon|Sean]]'s project called "The Peace Choir", performing a new version of Lennon's "[[Give Peace a Chance]]".{{cite web |author= |url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JyzSk8HVZTc&list=PL242CC9D560F594C5&index=1 |title=Peace Choir Give Peace a Chance |publisher=YouTube |date=August 20, 2009 |accessdate=April 19, 2014}} On November 24, 1991, Lauper married actor [[David Thornton (actor)|David Thornton]].{{cite web |last=Neustatter |first=Angela |title=How We Met: 41. David Thornton and Cyndi Lauper |url= http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/how-we-met-41-david-thornton-and-cyndi-lauper-1531454.html |newspaper=The Independent |accessdate=December 14, 2012 |date=July 5, 1992}} ===1993–1995: ''Hat Full of Stars'' and ''Twelve Deadly Cyns''=== Lauper's fourth album ''[[Hat Full of Stars]]'' was released in June 1993 and was met with critical acclaim, but failed commercially, unsupported by her label. The album, which tackled such topics as [[homophobia]], [[spousal abuse]], racism, and abortion sold fewer than 120,000 copies in the United States and peaked at No. 112 on the ''Billboard'' charts.{{cite web |url= {{BillboardURLbyName |artist=cyndi lauper |bio=true}} |title=– quote: "... Hat Full of Stars ... The record stiffed, peaking at 112 |work=Billboard |date= |accessdate=October 15, 2011}} The video for the album's song "[[Sally's Pigeons]]" features the then-unknown [[Julia Stiles]] as the young Cyndi.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} Lauper co-wrote several songs for the album with [[Mary Chapin Carpenter]], Ailee Willis, Nicky Holland, [[Tom Gray]], [[Hugh Masekela]] and [[The Hooters]]. That same year, Lauper recorded "Boys Will Be Boys" with The Hooters for their album ''[[Out of Body (album)|Out of Body]]''. The Hooters dedicated their song "[[Private Emotion]]" to her.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} The greatest hits album, ''[[Twelve Deadly Cyns...and Then Some]]'', was released outside of the US in 1994 and reached US audiences in summer of 1995. It included two re-recorded tracks, "I'm Gonna be Strong", originally recorded with Blue Angel, and a reworking of her first hit, newly christened "[[Girls Just Want to Have Fun|Hey Now (Girls Just Want to Have Fun)]]". In 1993, Lauper returned to acting, playing [[Michael J. Fox]]'s ditzy secretary in ''[[Life with Mikey]]''. She also won an [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Guest Actress - Comedy Series|Emmy Award]]{{cite web |url= http://www.emmys.com/celebrities/cyndi-lauper |title=Cyndi Lauper | Television Academy |publisher=Emmys.com |date= |accessdate=April 19, 2014}} for her role as Marianne in the sitcom ''[[Mad About You]]''.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} ===1996–2000: Motherhood and ''Sisters of Avalon''=== [[File:Cyndi blue hair 2000.jpg|thumb|left|Lauper performing in 2000]] On November 19, 1997, Lauper gave birth to her son Declyn Wallace Thornton.{{cite news | title = PUBLIC LIVES; In Their Words | author = | first = James| last = Barron| authorlink = James Barron (journalist)| author2 = Phoebe Hoban | url = http://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/28/nyregion/public-lives-in-their-words.html?scp=2&sq=cyndi+lauper&st=nyt| newspaper = [[The New York Times]]| date = January 28, 1998| accessdate = May 9, 2010 }} Her fifth album, ''[[Sisters of Avalon]]'', was released in Japan in 1996 and elsewhere in 1997. The album was written and produced with the help of Jan Pulsford (Lauper's keyboard player) and producer Mark Saunders. As in ''Hat Full of Stars'', some of the songs in ''Sisters of Avalon'' addressed dark themes. The song "[[Ballad of Cleo and Joe]]" addressed the complications of a [[drag queen]]'s double life. The song "Say a Prayer" was written for a friend of hers who had died from AIDS. "Unhook the Stars" was used in the [[Unhook the Stars|movie of the same name]]. Again without support from her label, the release failed in America, spending a single week on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' album chart at No. 188. This album also met with much critical praise, including ''People'' magazine, which declared it "90s nourishment for body and soul. Lauper sets a scene, makes us care, gives us hope."{{cite web|author= |url= http://www.frontandcenter.com/albums/cyndi-lauper/#comment-1279 |title=Cyndi Lauper | Front & Center |publisher=Frontandcenter.com |date= |accessdate=April 19, 2014}} In November 1998, Lauper released the Christmas album ''[[Merry Christmas...Have a Nice Life]]''. The album contained both original material and standards, and was co-produced and mixed by William Wittman.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} On January 17, 1999, Lauper appeared as an animated version of herself in ''[[The Simpsons]]'' episode "[[Wild Barts Can't Be Broken]]", singing the National Anthem to the melody of "Girls Just Want to Have Fun". In the same year, Lauper opened for [[Cher]]'s ''[[Do You Believe? Tour]]'' alongside [[Wild Orchid (band)|Wild Orchid]].{{citation needed|date=November 2012}} She also appeared in the films ''[[Mrs. Parker and the Vicious Circle]]'' and ''[[The Opportunists]]''.List of Movies Cyndi Lauper has appeared in, www.bangor.ac.uk/~iss082/movies.htmCyndi Lauper bio, www.imdb.com Lauper contributed a [[cover song|cover version]] of [[The Trammps]]' "[[Disco Inferno]]" to the soundtrack for the film ''[[A Night at the Roxbury]]''. The song was also released as an EP and earned Lauper a nomination [[1999 Grammy Awards]] for [[Best Dance Recording]]. In 2000, Lauper contributed the song "I Want a Mom That Will Last Forever" to the children's movie ''[[Rugrats in Paris]]''. The song was written with [[Mark Mothersbaugh]]. In 2000, Lauper also co-wrote the song "If You Believe" with [[Faye Tozer]] of the British pop group [[Steps (group)|Steps]], for the band's third studio album, ''[[Buzz (Steps album)|Buzz]]''.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} ===2001–2004: ''Shine'' and ''At Last''=== In 2001, Lauper prepared a new album ''[[Shine (Cyndi Lauper album)|Shine]]''. The album was a return to her early punk-rock sound and featured Japanese pop superstar [[Ryuichi Sakamoto]], and George Fullan of [[Train (band)|Train]]. Just weeks before the album's scheduled release on September 11, 2001, her label ([[Edel AG|Edel America Records]]) folded. A five-song [[Extended play|EP]] of ''Shine'' was released in June 2002, but the full-length album was released exclusively in Japan. An album of ''Shine'' remixes was eventually released through [[Tower Records]].{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} On October 12, 2000, Lauper took part in the television show ''Women in Rock, Girls with Guitars'' performing with [[Ann Wilson]] of [[Heart (band)|Heart]] and with the [[girl group]], [[Destiny's Child]]. A CD of the songs performed was released exclusively to [[Sears, Roebuck & Company|Sears]] stores from September 30 to October 31, 2001, and was marketed as a fundraiser for [[breast cancer]].{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} In 2002, Sony issued a best-of CD, ''[[The Essential Cyndi Lauper]]''. Lauper also released a cover album with Sony/[[Epic Records]] entitled ''[[At Last (Cyndi Lauper album)|At Last]]'' (formerly ''Naked City''), which was released in 2003. ''At Last'' received one nomination at the [[47th Grammy Awards|2005 Grammy Awards]]: [[Grammy Award for Best Instrumental Arrangement Accompanying Vocalist(s)|Best Instrumental Arrangement Accompanying Vocalist(s)]], for "[[Unchained Melody]]". The effort was also a commercial hit, selling 4.5 million records{{cite web |url= http://www.thebiographychannel.co.uk/biographies/cyndi-lauper.html |title=BIOGRAPHY: Cyndi Lauper Lifetime |publisher=Thebiographychannel.co.uk |date= |accessdate=April 19, 2014}} In April 2004, Lauper performed during the [[VH1]]'s benefit concert [[VH1 Divas|Divas Live 2004]] alongside [[Ashanti (entertainer)|Ashanti]], [[Gladys Knight]], [[Jessica Simpson]], [[Joss Stone]] and [[Patti LaBelle]], in support of the Save the Music Foundation.{{cite web|url= http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0409423/fullcredits?ref_=tt_cl_sm#castDivas |title=Live 2004 |publisher=IMDb.com |accessdate=September 19, 2014}} ===2005–2007: ''The Body Acoustic''=== In 2005, under a new contract with Sony Music, Lauper released ''[[The Body Acoustic]]'', an album that featured acoustic reinterpretations of tracks from her repertoire. The album also included two new tracks, one of which was "Above the Clouds". Guest performers on the album included [[Shaggy (musician)|Shaggy]], [[Ani DiFranco]], [[Adam Lazzara]] of [[Taking Back Sunday]], [[Jeff Beck]], [[Puffy AmiYumi]], [[Sarah McLachlan]], and [[Vivian Green]]. "Time After Time" with Sarah McLachlan charted on the [[Billboard (magazine)|''Billboard'']] Adult Contemporary chart.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} She made appearances on [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]]'s hit show ''[[Queer as Folk (US TV series)|Queer As Folk]]'' in 2005, directed a commercial for ''Totally 80s'' edition of the board game ''[[Trivial Pursuit]]'' in 2006, served as a judge on the 6th Annual [[Independent Music Awards]] and made her Broadway debut in the Tony-nominated ''[[The Threepenny Opera]]'' as Jenny. She performed with [[Shaggy (musician)|Shaggy]], [[Scott Weiland]] of [[Velvet Revolver]]/[[Stone Temple Pilots]], [[Pat Monahan]] of [[Train (band)|Train]], [[Ani DiFranco]], and [[The Hooters]] in the [[VH1 Classics]] special [[Decades Rock Live]]. In 2007, she sang "Beecharmer" with Nellie McKay on McKay's ''[[Pretty Little Head]]'' album, and "Letters To Michael" with [[Dionne Warwick]].{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} On October 16, 2006, Lauper was inducted into the [[Long Island Music Hall of Fame]].{{cite web|url= http://www.limusichalloffame.org |title=Long Island Music Hall of Fame | Preserving & Celebrating the Long Island musical heritage |publisher=Limusichalloffame.org |date= |accessdate=April 19, 2014}} ===2008–2009: ''Bring Ya to the Brink''=== [[File:Cyndi Lauper2 cropped.jpg|thumb|left|Cyndi Lauper performing in 2008]] In 2009, Lauper took a role and wrote a song for the [[Serbs|Serbian]] movie ''[[Here and There (film)|Here and There]]'', which stars her husband, David Thornton.{{citation needed |date=September 2014}} Lauper's sixth studio album, ''[[Bring Ya to the Brink]]'' was released in the United States on May 27, 2008. By the time of the album's US release, the single "[[Set Your Heart]]" had already had significant airplay in Japan, and Lauper had begun an Australian tour with [[Katie Noonan]] and [[Kate Miller-Heidke]]. The album featured dance tracks written with artists including [[Axwell]], [[The Scumfrog]], [[Basement Jaxx]], [[Digital Dog]], [[Dragonette]], [[Kleerup]], and others. ''Bring Ya to the Brink'' received one Grammy nomination for [[Best Electronic/Dance Album]] and charted two #1 hits on the ''Billboard'' Dance chart. "[[Set Your Heart]]" was used in the Japanese advertising campaign for the 2008 [[Toyota]] MarkX ZIO.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} {{listen |filename=Cyndi Lauper - Into the Nightlife.ogg |title="Into the Nightlife" |Type=single}} Other projects for 2008 included the True Colors Tour and a Christmas duet with Swedish band [[The Hives]], entitled "[[A Christmas Duel]]". The song was released as a CD single and a 7" vinyl in Sweden.{{cite web|url=http://www.sverigetopplistan.se/ |title=Sverigetopplistan – Sveriges Officiella Topplista |publisher=Sverigetopplistan.se |date= |accessdate=October 15, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151226154145/http://www.sverigetopplistan.se/ |archivedate=December 26, 2015 |df=mdy }} Lauper also performed on the "Girls Night Out", headlining it with [[Rosie O'Donnell]] in the US.{{cite web|url= http://www.cyndilauper.com/index.php?module=tour |title=Tour: Summer 2009: Girls Night Out Tour with Rosie O'Donnell |publisher=Cyndi Lauper |date= |accessdate=October 15, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100504202130/http://www.cyndilauper.com/index.php?module=tour |archivedate=May 4, 2010 |df=mdy }} Lauper's TV appearances in 2009 included the American soap opera ''[[As the World Turns]]'', performing "[[Time After Time (Cyndi Lauper song)|Time After Time]]" as a duet with [[Allison Iraheta]], on the season 8 finale of ''[[American Idol]]'' and at the 2009 TV Land Awards on April 19 dressed as the "Empress of Evil" for a musical tribute to [[Sid Krofft|Sid]] and [[Marty Krofft]]. Lauper performed a duet with [[Leona Lewis]] on VH1 Divas on September 19, 2009, singing "True Colors", and performed a comedy skit with [[Eminem]] at the MTV VMA's in September 2009. She also played herself in ''[[30 Rock]]'''s third season finale and appeared as Avalon Harmonia, a psychic, on the Season 5 premiere of ''[[Bones (TV series)|Bones]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt1475714/ |title=Harbingers in a Fountain}} On November 17, 2009, Lauper performed a collaborative work with [[Wyclef Jean]] called "Slumdog Millionaire", performing it on the ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]''.{{cite web|url= http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.10140/title.wyclef-jean-cyndi-lauper-to-perform-on-david-letterman |title= Wyclef Jean & Cyndi Lauper To Perform On David Letterman |accessdate=November 17, 2009 }} The collaborative effort stems from Jean's latest album: ''Toussaint St. Jean: [[From the Hut, To the Projects, To the Mansion]]''.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} ===2010–2012: ''The Celebrity Apprentice'', ''Memphis Blues'', memoir=== In January 2010, [[Mattel]] released a Cyndi Lauper [[Barbie]] doll as part of their "Ladies of the 80s" series.{{cite web| url=http://jezebel.com/5389459/barbie-doll-versions-of-joan-jett-debbie-harry-and-cyndi-lauper-arriving-in-december |title=Barbie Doll Versions Of Joan Jett, Debbie Harry, And Cyndi Lauper Arriving In December |first=Hortense |last=Smith |work=jezebel.com |accessdate=July 27, 2016}} In March 2010, Lauper appeared on [[NBC]]'s [[The Apprentice (U.S. season 9)|''The Celebrity Apprentice'']], coming in sixth place.{{cite web|author= |url=http://newsroom.mtv.com/2010/05/10/celebrity-apprentice-recap-cyndi-lauper/ |title='The Celebrity Apprentice' Recap: Cyndi Lauper's True Colors Catch Up With Her |publisher=Newsroom.mtv.com |date=May 10, 2010 |accessdate=April 19, 2014}} She donated her winnings to her True Colors Fund. Lauper also performed a song from her upcoming album ''[[Memphis Blues (album)|Memphis Blues]]'' in the show's live season finale.{{cite web|url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YQUXp-igra4 |title=Celebrity Apprentice FINAL ( Cyndi Lauper,Donald Trump,Holly,Bret Michaels ) |publisher=YouTube |date=August 11, 2010 |accessdate=April 19, 2014}} ''Memphis Blues''—Lauper's 7th studio album—was released on June 22, 2010 and debuted on the ''Billboard'' Blues Albums chart at No. 1, and at No. 26 on the ''Billboard'' Top 200. The album remained No. 1 on the Blues Albums chart for 14 consecutive weeks; ''Memphis Blues'' was nominated for [[Best Traditional Blues Album]] at the [[2011 Grammy Awards]].{{cite web|url= http://highlineballroom.com/show/2013/12/09/front-center-with-cyndi-lauper/ |title=Front & Center with Cyndi Lauper – Highline Ballroom |work=Highline Ballroom |accessdate=September 19, 2014}} Lauper made international news in March 2011 for an impromptu performance of "Girls Just Want to Have Fun" while waiting for a delayed flight at [[Aeroparque Jorge Newbery]] in Buenos Aires. A video was later posted on YouTube.{{cite web|url= http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/wireStory?id=13076997 |title=Cyndi Lauper Cheers Stuck Travelers in Argentina – ABC News |publisher=ABC News |date=March 7, 2011 |accessdate=October 15, 2011}}{{cite news| url=http://newsfeed.time.com/2011/03/08/watch-cyndi-laupers-impromptu-airport-performance-of-girls-just-wanna-have-fun/ |title= Watch Cyndi Laupers impromptu airport performance of girls just wanna have fun |work=Time | date=March 8, 2011}} In November 2011, she released two Christmas singles exclusive to [[iTunes]]. The first release was a Blues-inspired cover of [[Elvis Presley]]'s classic "[[Blue Christmas (song)|Blue Christmas]]", and the second was a new version of "[[Home For The Holidays (song)|Home for the holidays]]", a duet with [[Norah Jones]]. In June 2012, Lauper made her first appearance for [[WWE]] in 27 years, to promote [[WWE Raw]]'s 1000th episode to memorialize "Captain" [[Lou Albano]].{{cite web|url= http://www.wwe.com/videos/rowdy-roddy-piper-talks-about-his-rock-n-wrestling-reunion-with-cyndi-lauper-wwe-26031884 |title="Rowdy" Roddy Piper talks about his "Rock 'N' Wrestling" reunion with Cyndi Lauper: WWE.com Exclusive |work=WWE |accessdate=September 19, 2014}} In September 2012, Lauper performed at fashion designer [[Betsey Johnson]]'s 40 year Retrospective Fashion show.{{cite web |last=Leung |first=Mariana |url= http://www.msfabulous.com/2012/09/betsey-johnson-and-cyndi-lauper-ny.html |title=Betsey Johnson and Cyndi Lauper – NY Fashion Week fashion design, indie clothing, style, beauty |publisher=Ms. Fabulous |date=September 12, 2012 |accessdate=April 19, 2014}} She also released a ''New York Times'' Best Selling memoir that detailed her struggle with [[child abuse]] and depression.{{cite web|url= http://broadwayworld.com/article/Cyndi-Lauper-Wins-Tony-for-Best-Original-Score-20130609/ |title=Cyndi Lauper Wins Tony for Best Original Score |accessdate=2013-06-13 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20130613080806/http://broadwayworld.com/article/Cyndi-Lauper-Wins-Tony-for-Best-Original-Score-20130609/ |archivedate=June 13, 2013 |df=mdy }} ===2013–2015: ''Kinky Boots, She's So Unusual: A 30th Anniversary Celebration'' & Songwriters Hall of Fame=== Lauper composed music for the Broadway musical ''[[Kinky Boots (musical)|Kinky Boots]]'' with [[Harvey Fierstein]]. The musical was based on the 2006 independent film ''[[Kinky Boots (film)|Kinky Boots]].'' It opened in Chicago in October 2012''Entertainment Weekly'', May 18, 2012. and on Broadway at the [[Al Hirschfeld Theatre]] on April 4, 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.kinkybootsthemusical.com/ |title=Kinky Boots – Official Broadway Site |publisher=Kinkybootsthemusical.com |date= |accessdate=April 19, 2014}} In May, Lauper won for best score for ''[[Kinky Boots (musical)|Kinky Boots]]'' at the 63rd annual [[Outer Critics Circle Awards]].[http://www.dispatch.com/content/blogs/theatre-talk/2013/05/outer-critics-circle-noms.html/ ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130912130528/http://www.dispatch.com/content/blogs/theatre-talk/2013/05/outer-critics-circle-noms.html/ |date=September 12, 2013 }} The musical led the [[67th Tony Awards|2013 Tony Awards]], with 13 nominations and six wins including [[Tony Award for Best Musical|Best Musical]] and [[Tony Award for Best Actor in a Musical|Best Actor]]. Lauper won the award for [[Tony Award for Best Original Score|Best Original Score]].{{cite news|url=http://www.upi.com/blog/2013/06/09/Cyndi-Lauper-wins-big-at-the-Tony-Awards/9821370827500/ |title=Cyndi Lauper wins Tony for Best Original Score |publisher=UPI |date=June 13, 2013|accessdate=June 9, 2013}} Lauper was the first woman to win solo in this category.{{cite news| url=http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/04/30/tony-awards-2013-nominations-live-blog/ | work=The New York Times | first=Patrick | last=Healy | title='Kinky Boots' Leads With 13 Tony Nominations; Tom Hanks Gets Nod for 'Lucky Guy' | date=April 30, 2013}} In the summer of 2013, in celebration of the 30th anniversary of her debut album ''[[She's So Unusual]]'', Lauper embarked on an international tour covering America and Australia. The show consisted of a mix of fan favorites and the entirety of the ''She's So Unusual'' record. Independent|accessdate=September 19, 2014}} It featured a remastered version of the original album plus three new remixes. The Deluxe Edition featured bonus tracks such as demos and a live recording as well as a 3D cut-out of the bedroom featured in the 'Girls Just Want to Have Fun' music video with a reusable sticker set.{{cite web|url=http://cyndilauper.com/news/#/news-story/cyndi-lauper-celebrates-her-record-breaking-debut-album-with-shes-so-unusual-a-30th-anniversary-celebration/|title=News – Cyndi Lauper|publisher=Cyndilauper.com|accessdate=September 19, 2014}} On September 17, 2014, Cyndi Lauper sang on the finale of [[America's Got Talent]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv/america-talent-finale-adds-cyndi-lauper-travis-barker-article-1.1941021|title='America's Got Talent' finale adds Cyndi Lauper, Travis Barker to celebrity line-up |work=NY Daily News|accessdate=September 19, 2014}} On September 25, as part of the [[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today Show]]'s Shine a Light series, Lauper re-recorded "[[True Colors (Cyndi Lauper song)|True Colors]]" in a mashup with [[Sara Bareilles]]' "[[Brave (Sara Bareilles song)|Brave]]" to raise awareness and money for children battling cancer.{{cite web|url=http://www.today.com/news/watch-hoda-kotb-sara-bareilles-cyndi-lauper-fight-pediatric-cancer-2D80172642|title=Watch: Hoda Kotb, Sara Bareilles, Cyndi Lauper fight pediatric cancer with "Truly Brave' music video - News - TODAY.com|first=Robin|last=Sindler|work=TODAY}} By October the project had raised over $300,000.{{cite web|url=https://www.crowdrise.com/hoda|title=Hoda Kotb – Hoda Kotb's Fundraiser on CrowdRise|work=crowdrise.com}} The [[Songwriters Hall of Fame]] included Lauper in its nomination list on October 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.songhall.org/news/entry/songwriters_hall_of_fame_2014_nominees_for_induction_announced|title=SongHall – Songwriters Hall Of Fame 2014 Nominees For Induction Announced|work=songhall.org}} Also during October, Lauper's fourth consecutive 'Home for the Holidays' benefit concert for [[homeless]] gay youth was announced. Acts included [[50 Cent]] and [[Laverne Cox]] with 100% of the net proceeds going to the True Colors Fund{{cite web|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/50-cent-laverne-cox-join-cyndi-lauper-to-help-lgbt-youth-20141022|author=Daniel Kreps|title=50 Cent, Laverne Cox Join Cyndi Lauper to Help LGBT Youth|work=Rolling Stone|date=October 22, 2014}} In March 2015 Lauper once again guest starred on the crime show Bones as Avalon Harmonia.{{cite web|url=http://www.tvfanatic.com/2015/03/bones-round-table-cyndi-lauper-and-body-stew/|title=Bones|work=TV Fanatic}} On June 12, 2015, Lauper appeared on ''[[The Graham Norton Show]]'' alongside [[Seth MacFarlane]], [[Dara O'Briain]], and [[Mark Wahlberg]]. To promote her work with the National Psoriasis Foundation and Novartis and revealing she, herself has suffered from [[psoriasis]] for the past five years, Cyndi appeared on the ''[[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today Show]]'' in July 2015. During the interview Cyndi revealed she is working on a project with [[Seymour Stein]]. Later it was revealed in an interview with Rolling Stone she is working on a country album with [[Tony Brown (record producer)|Tony Brown]], and Seymour Stein as executive producer.{{cite web|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/premieres/hear-cyndi-lauper-cover-dolly-partons-hard-candy-christmas-20151208|title=Hear Cyndi Lauper Cover Dolly Parton's 'Hard Candy Christmas'|work=Rolling web|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/hear-cyndi-laupers-rockabilly-take-on-heartaches-by-the-number-20160128|title=Hear Cyndi Lauper's Rockabilly Take on 'Heartaches by the Ballerini]] and [[Ingrid Michaelson]].{{cite web|url=http://www.countryweekly.com/news/skyville-live-shines-again-cyndi-lauper-kelsea-ballerini-and-ingrid-michaelson|title=Skyville Live Shines Again With Cyndi Lauper, Kelsea Ballerini and Ingrid Michaelson|work=Country Weekly}} On February 17, 2016 she released her version of [[Wanda Jackson]]'s "[[Funnel of Love]]"{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/article/cyndi-lauper-funnel-of-love-detour-country-album|title=Cyndi Lauper Goes Country on New Single 'Funnel of Love' (FIRST LISTEN)|work=People}} In February 2016, Lauper was nominated for an [[Laurence Olivier Award|Olivier Award]] for her contribution to the UK production of "Kinky Boots" along with [[Stephen Oremus]], the man responsible for the arrangements.{{cite web|url=http://europe.newsweek.com/olivier-awards-2016-gypsy-and-kinky-boots-lead-nominations-431986?rm=eu|title=Olivier Awards 2016: 'Gypsy' and 'Kinky Boots' lead nominations|work=Newsweek Europe}} In May 2016, [[Jean-Michel Jarre]] shipped Electronica 2 The Heart of Noise, the second album of the Electronica project, based on collaborations with artists related to electronic music (Tangerine Dream, Moby, Pet Shop Boys, etc.). This second album has a song (Swipe to the Right) product of the collaboration between Jarre and Lauper. Her son, Dex Lauper, will be opening Cyndi's October 8 Las Vegas concert date for her [[Detour Tour]] with 2 of his own songs. ==Activism== [[File:Cyndi Lauper at Gay Games VII.jpg|thumb|200px|Lauper performing at the Gay Games VII, Wrigley Field, July 22, 2006]] Lauper has been an LGBT rights supporter throughout her career, campaigning for equality through various charities and [[gay pride]] events around the world. Lauper stated that she became involved in gay rights advocacy because her sister Ellen is a lesbian and because Lauper herself was passionate about equality. Lauper cites her sister Ellen as a role model.{{cite web|url=http://thegavoice.com/cyndi-laupers-true-colors/|title=Cyndi Lauper’s ‘True Colors’|publisher=GA Voice|accessdate=January 23, 2016|date=July 23, 2010}} Her song "Above the Clouds" celebrates the memory of [[Matthew Shepard]], a young man beaten to death in Wyoming because he was gay. As a member of the [[Matthew Shepard Foundation]] Board, Lauper devoted a [[concert tour]] in 2005 to promoting the Foundation's message.{{cite web|url=http://www.advocate.com/arts-entertainment/entertainment-news/2005/12/14/cyndi-lauper-joins-honorary-board-matthew-shepard|title=Cyndi Lauper joins honorary board of Matthew Shepard Foundation|publisher=The Advocate|accessdate=January 23, 2016|date=December 14, 2005}} She co-founded the [[True Colors World Tour]] for Human Rights throughout the United States and Canada in June 2007. One dollar from each ticket was earmarked for the [[Human Rights Campaign]], which advocates equal rights for LGBT individuals.{{cite web|url=http://www.abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/wireStory?id=2943293 |title=Lauper, Others Headline Gay Rights Tour |publisher=ABC News |date= |accessdate=October 15, 2011}} In April 2010, Lauper's True Colors Fund launched the Give a Damn campaign, to help get straight people more involved in LGBT rights. In 2012 Lauper started the ''Forty to None Project'' after learning that while 10% of American youth identify themselves as LGBT, up to 40% of American homeless youths do so. She set up the ''True Colors Residence'' in New York City for LGBT homeless youths. The 30-bed facility offers temporary shelter and job placement help.{{cite news|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/cyndi-lauper-opens-shelter-for-homeless-lgbt-youth-20110825|title=Cyndi Lauper Opens Shelter for Homeless LGBT Youth |publisher=rollingstone.com |date=August 25, 2011 |accessdate=August 28, 2015 |first=Inae |last=Oh}} In August 2008, she contributed an article titled "Hope" to ''[[The Huffington Post]]'', encouraging Americans to vote for [[Barack Obama]] in the [[United States presidential election, 2008|upcoming United States presidential election]].{{cite web|author=Lauper, Cyndi|date=August 24, 2008|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/cyndi-lauper/hope_b_120936.html|title=Hope|work=The Huffington Post|accessdate=August 30, 2008}} Lauper performed at the [[2008 Democratic National Convention]]. ==Legacy== Lauper was one of the earliest female artists to harness MTV.{{clarify|date=February 2016}} She was described by [[AllMusic]]'s Lindsay Planer as "an iconoclastic vocalist who revolutionized the role of women in rock and roll."{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/blue-angel-mw0000770882|title=Blue Angel – Blue Angel – Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards – AllMusic|work=AllMusic|accessdate=September 19, 2014}} Over her thirty-year career, she influenced multiple recording artists including [[Katy Perry]],{{cite news|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/2295376/what-will-katy-perrys-new-album-sound-like-check-out-5-video-clues/|title=What Will Katy Perry’s New Album Sound Like? Check Out 5 Video Clues |first=Chris|last=Ryan|publisher=MTV News|date=March 30, 2010|accessdate=March 26, 2016}} [[Alanis Morissette]], [[Britney Spears]], [[Christina Aguilera]], [[India Arie]], [[Jewel (singer)|Jewel]], [[Jill Scott]], [[Joan Osborne]], [[Kasey Chambers]], [[Maximum Balloon]], [[No Doubt]], [[Pink (singer)|P!nk]], [[Sophie B. Hawkins]], [[Vanessa Paradis]],{{cite web|url=http://musicbloodline.info/artist/MN0000122754/spotify |title=Cyndi Lauper | Music Bloodline |publisher=Musicbloodline.info |date= |accessdate=April 19, 2014}} [[Tegan and Sara]],{{cite web|last=Maloy |first=Sarah |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/candid-covers/1481449/watch-tegan-sara-sing-cyndi-lauper-candid-covers |title=Watch Tegan & Sara Sing Cyndi Lauper: Candid Covers |publisher=''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' |date=December 12, 2012 |accessdate=April 4, 2015}} [[Nicki Minaj]], [[Kelly Clarkson]], [[Lil' Kim]], [[Lady Gaga]], [[Little Boots]], and [[Yelle]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/artists/cyndi-lauper/related-artists/?filter=followers |title=Cyndi Lauper Followers |publisher=MTV |date= |accessdate=April 19, 2014}} Due to her success and influence Lauper has been inducted in to both the Hollywood and Songwriters Hall of Fame.{{cite web|url=http://www.usnews.com/news/entertainment/articles/2015/06/22/tarantino-lauper-others-chosen-for-hollywood-walk-of-fame|title=Tarantino, Lauper, others chosen for Hollywood Walk of Fame – US News|work=US News & World Report}} [[Stephen Thomas Erlewine]] of [[Spotify]] notes that ''She's So Unusual'' and her distinctive idiosyncratic appearance "helped popularize the image of punk and new wave for America, making it an acceptable part of the pop landscape". ''Rolling Stone ''magazine stated that her debut was "arguably the first time explicitly punk-influenced elements were front-and-center on the pop landscape, both musically and via Lauper's Patrick Lucas-styled ensembles, dressing up the droll Reagan decade in feminist chutzpah."{{cite web|url=http://www.out.com/entertainment/music/2014/03/28/cyndi-lauper-releases-lost-track-iconic-shes-so-unusual-30th |title=Cyndi Lauper Releases Lost Track from Iconic She's So Unusual for 30th Anniversary Album | Out Magazine |publisher=Out.com |date=March 28, 2014 |accessdate=April 19, 2014}} The album ranked at #487 on ''[[Rolling Stone]]''{{'}}s list of [[The 500 Greatest Albums of All Time]] in 2003. The album ranked at #41 on ''Rolling Stone''{{'}}s list of Women Who Rock: The 50 Greatest Albums of All Time in 2012.{{cite journal|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/women-who-rock-the-50-greatest-albums-of-all-time-20120622 |title=Women Who Rock: The 50 Greatest Albums of All Time |magazine=Rolling Stone |date= |accessdate=April 19, 2014}} ''Rolling Stone's'' review stated, "A wild and wonderful skyrocket of a voice... Lauper's extraordinary pipes connect with the right material, the results sound like the beginning of a whole new golden age." Thirty years after its release, the album was praised as 'everlasting' and a 'once in a lifetime album'.{{cite web|last=Ross |first=Dalton |url=http://music-mix.ew.com/2014/04/01/cyndi-lauper-shes-so-unusual-30th-anniversary/ |title=Cyndi Lauper's 'She's So Unusual': An everlasting, once in a lifetime album | The Music Mix | EW.com |publisher=Music-mix.ew.com |date=April 1, 2014 |accessdate=April 19, 2014}} Her iconic cover and re-arrangement of "[[Girls Just Wanna Have Fun]]" established her as 'a feminist idol'. Sheila Moeschen argued that the song 'embodied a different kind of feminine aesthetic that ran counter to the raw sensuality and edginess of her contemporaries like Madonna or veteran rockers Joan Jett and Pat Benatar' that introduced 'a nation of women to a new kind of female role model, one that celebrated difference and encouraged playfulness in self-expression'.{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/sheila-moeschen/girls-still-just-wanna-have-fun_b_3061316.html | work=Huffington Post | first=Sheila | last=Moeschen | title=Girls Still Just Wanna Have Fun: At 30, Cyndi Lauper's Feminist Anthem Endures | date=April 11, 2013}} [[John Rockwell]] wrote that the song was "a giddily upbeat attestation to female pleasure that simultaneously made a feminist statement, fulfilled male fantasies and—especially in its often-played video version—evoked the warmth of family and friends."{{cite web|last=Green |first=Emma |url=http://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2014/04/the-feisty-feminism-of-girls-just-want-to-have-fun-30-years-later/359834/ |title=The Feisty Feminism of 'Girls Just Want to Have Fun,' 30 Years Later – Emma Green |work=The Atlantic |date=April 1, 2014 |accessdate=April 19, 2014}} The video for "Girls" won the first-ever Best Female Video prize at the 1984 VMAs. It featured a multicultural cast of women with teased, sideways hair and neon eye shadow, singing alongside Lauper. She was the first woman to have four Top 5 hits from a debut album, the first woman to win the composing category solo during the 2013 Tony Awards and one of only four women to have won competitive Grammy, Emmy and Tony awards.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} Lauper's song "Time After Time" has been covered by over 100 artists and was ranked at #22 on ''Rolling Stone''{{'}}s 100 Best Songs of the Past 25 Years{{cite web|url=http://www.rockonthenet.com/archive/2003/vh125songs.htm |title=VH1: 100 Best Songs of the Past 25 Years: 1–50 |publisher=Rock On The Net |date= |accessdate=November 15, 2012}} and at #19 on [[VH1]]'s 100 Greatest Songs of the 80s.{{cite web|url=http://www.rockonthenet.com/archive/2006/vh180s.htm |title=VH1: 100 Greatest Songs of the 80's: 1–50 |publisher=Rock On The Net |date= |accessdate=November 15, 2012}} "[[She Bop]]", the third single from ''She's So Unusual ''made history as the first and only top ten song to directly mention a [[gay porn]] magazine.{{cite web|url=http://www.thebacklot.com/the-essential-cyndi-lauper-ranking-her-top-20-songs/06/2014/2/|title=The Essential Cyndi Lauper: Ranking Her Top 20 Songs|work=thebacklot.com|accessdate=September 19, 2014}} The single was included in the PMRC's "Filthy Fifteen" list that led to the [[parental advisory]] sticker that marked recordings thought to be unsuitable for young listeners. In their 1984 retrospective ''Rolling Stone'' listed She Bop as the 36th best song of that year, praising it for its unusual playfulness regarding sexuality.{{cite web|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/100-best-singles-of-1984-pops-greatest-year-20140917/cyndi-lauper-she-bop-20140917|title=Cyndi Lauper, "She Bop"|work=Rolling Stone}} Her song "True Colors" is recognized by many as an LGBT anthem. Her many projects supporting LGBT rights made her a gay icon.{{cite web|url=http://www.towleroad.com/2014/02/gay-iconography-cyndi-lauper-is-a-not-so-unusual-choice-1.html |title=Gay Iconography: Cyndi Lauper Is A Not-So-Unusual Choice| Gay News |publisher=Towleroad |date= |accessdate=April 19, 2014}} ==Discography== {{Main article|Cyndi Lauper discography}} {{Further information|Blue Angel (band)#Discography}} * ''[[She's So Unusual]]'' (1983) * ''[[True Colors (Cyndi Lauper album)|True Colors]]'' (1986) * ''[[A Night to Remember (Cyndi Lauper album)|A Night to Remember]]'' (1989) * ''[[Hat Full of Stars]]'' (1993) * ''[[Sisters of Avalon]]'' (1996) * ''[[Merry Christmas...
